An Interpenetrating Architecture Based on the Wells–Dawson Polyoxometalate and AgI···AgI Interactions

    An Interpenetrating Architecture Based on the Wells–Dawson Polyoxometalate and AgI···AgI Interactions

    • Peng-peng Zhang†
      • , 
    • Jun Peng*†
      • , 
    • Hai-jun Pang†
      • , 
    • Jing-quan Sha‡
      • , 
    • Min Zhu†
      • , 
    • Dan-dan Wang†
      • , 
    • Ming-guan Liu†
      • , and 
    • Zhong-min Su†
    View Author Information
    Key Laboratory of Polyoxometalate Science of Ministry of Education, Faculty of Chemistry, Northeast Normal University, Changchun, Jilin 130024, P. R. China
    The Provincial Key Laboratory of Biological Medicine Formulation, School of Pharmacy, Jiamusi University, Jiamusi, 154007, P. R. China
    Tel: +86 4315099765; fax: +86-431-5099667. E-mail: jpeng@nenu.edu.cn
    Cite this: Cryst. Growth Des. 2011, 11, 7, 2736–2742
    Publication Date (Web):May 9, 2011

    SUBJECTS:

    Crystal Growth & Design
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A new compound based on the Wells–Dawson polyoxometalate, Ag7(bbi)5(OH)(P2W18O62) (bbi = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole)) (1), has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by the normal physical methods and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 represents the first interpenetrating framework based on the Wells–Dawson POMs. The AgI···AgI interactions are crucial in the formation of the two individual motifs: in the first interpenetrating motif, the supported {Ag2}2+ dimers and the P2W18 polyanions form an infinite inorganic chain, then the Ag+ monomers and bbi ligands extend the chain to form a three-dimensional framework. The second motif is constructed by the Ag–bbi meso-helix chains which are stitched by the unsupported Ag7···Ag7 dimers to form a two-dimensional layer with huge loops. The electrochemical study exhibits that compound 1 could be used as electrocatalyst in the electrical reductions of bromate. In addition, compound 1 shows a photocatalytic action for degradation of RhB.

    Synopsis

    Ag7(bbi)5(OH)(P2W18O62) (bbi = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole)) (1) exhibits a 2D + 3D interpenetrating architecture in which the AgI···AgI interactions are crucial in the formation of the two individual motifs.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Photocatalytic Activity
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Interpenetrating frameworks are described as architectures which cannot be separated except if one of the individual motifs is broken.(1) In their complicated architectures, supramolecular connections (such as electrostatic interaction, hydrogen bond, π–π stacking, and cation−π interactions) among the individual motifs endow them with structural flexibility, which is important in the applications of gas storage, conductivity, biological chemistry, and so on.(2) Interpenetration is a subclass of entangled system studied extensively and developed rapidly nowadays. Individual motifs of the interpenetrating architectures are from two-dimensional (2D) nets to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, and the number of interpenetrating units varies from 2 to 10.(3) Ongoing research in interpenetration focuses on the introduction of functional groups with available characters.
    Polyoxometalates (POMs) are early transition metal oxide clusters composed of Mo, W, V, Nb, and so on. POMs show a wide variety of interesting structural motifs with different sizes and topologies. Besides the classical Keggin, Wells–Dawson, Anderson, Waugh, Silverton, and Lindqvist types, many new structures have been found, such as closed cages, Wheels, dimeric anions, and transition-metal-centered heteropolyoxometalates.(4) POMs are in the nanosize scale and have abundant surface oxygen atoms, which make them excellent inorganic building blocks. In addition, POMs bear versatile properties in such fields as catalysis, photochemistry, magnetism, electrochemistry, and biochemistry.(5, 6)
    Accordingly, POM-based interpenetrating compounds will not only show aesthetic architectures but also possess both properties of flexibility of interpenetration and versatile functions of POMs.(7) However, to obtain such compounds is difficult as the nanosized POMs with a big steric hindrance would inhibit the formation of interpenetration.
    Ag+ ion is a prominent metal linker in the POM-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs), for it not only possesses abundant coordination modes such as linear, T-type, “seesaw”, “square-pyramidal”, “trigonal-bipyramidal” and octahedral geometries(8) but also is useful in the areas of catalysis, biological chemistry, and so on.(9) In addition, the argentophilicity of Ag+ ions may conduce the formation of {Ag2}2+ dimers, which may play a key role in the expansion of multiple dimensional structures. {Ag2}2+ dimers acting as linkers can be classified into unsupported and supported ones according to their coordination modes; that is, two Ag+ ions in an unsupported {Ag2}2+ dimer are fused only by AgI···AgI interaction, while those in a supported {Ag2}2+ dimer are connected not only by AgI···AgI interaction but also by other bridging groups (Scheme 1).(10) Recently, chemists have synthesized several POM-based compounds containing {Ag2}2+ dimers.(11) In most of these compounds, the {Ag2}2+ dimers adopt the supported mode which is achieved by coordination of polyanions or organic ligands. A typical unsupported example is [Ag(CH3CN)4]⊂{[Ag(CH3CN)2]4[H3W12O40]},(11a) in which the {Ag2}2+ dimers joint the discrete segments to form a 3D architecture.
    Herein, we describe a new compound, Ag7(bbi)5(OH)(P2W18O62) (1), obtained by combination of Wells–Dawson POM, Ag+ ion and the organic ligand bbi, in which the AgI···AgI interactions are crucial in the formation of the interpenetrating architecture. Unlike the examples mentioned above, the {Ag2}2+ dimers in compound 1 adopt both the supported and unsupported modes. Compound 1 represents the first interpenetrating framework based on the Wells–Dawson POMs and AgI···AgI interactions.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Photocatalytic Activity
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References

    Materials and General Methods

    All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. α-K6P2W18O62·15H2O and bbi were prepared according to the reported procedure and verified by IR spectrum.(12) Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The IR spectrum was obtained on Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer with KBr pellet in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. The solid UV–vis absorption was carried out on a Cary 500 spectrophotometer. The thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in flowing N2 on a Perkin-Elmer DTA 1700 differential thermal analyzer with a rate of 10.00 °C/min. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained with a CHI 660 electrochemical workstation at room temperature. Platinum gauze was used as a counter electrode and Ag/AgCl electrode was referenced. Chemically bulk-modified carbon paste electrode (CPE) was used as working electrode. The photocatalytic activity was tested by a 756 CRT UV–vis spectrophotometer.

    Synthesis of Ag7(bbi)5(OH)(P2W18O62) (1)

    A mixture of α-K6P2W18O62·15H2O (2 g, 0.4 mmol), AgNO3 (0.17 g, 1 mmol), bbi (0.4 g, 1 mmol), and NH4VO3 (0.12 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water at room temperature. When the pH of the mixture was adjusted to about 7.1 with 1.0 mol L–1 NaOH, the suspension was put into a Teflon-lined autoclave and kept under autogenous pressure at 160 °C for 4 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water (50% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C50H71Ag7N20O63P2W18 (6086.34): C 9.87, H 1.12, N 4.60. Found: C 9.89, H 1.15, N 4.64. IR (solid KBr pellet, cm–1): 3139 (w), 1690 (m), 1655 (m), 1519 (s), 1420 (w), 1344 (w), 1274 (w), 1225 (m), 1140 (w), 1087 (s), 954 (m), 909 (m), 783(s).

    Preparation of 1–CPE

    Compound 1 modified carbon paste electrode 1–CPE was prepared as follows: 90 mg of graphite powder and 8 mg of compound 1 were mixed and ground together by agate mortar and pestle to achieve a uniform mixture, and then 0.1 mL nujol was added with stirring. The homogenized mixture was packed into a glass tube with 1.5 mm inner diameter, and the tube surface was wiped with paper. Electrical contact was established with copper rod through the back of the electrode. Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode was used as a reference electrode, and a Pt wire as a counter electrode.

    Photocatalytic Reaction

    Powder of 60 mg compound 1 was dispersed into a 1.0 × 10–5 mol/L RhB aqueous solution. The solution was stirred in the dark for 30 min to ensure the establishment of adsorption equilibrium before irradiation. Then 3 mL aliquot was sampled and then centrifuged to remove the catalyst. The RhB concentration (C0) was determined by measuring the maximum absorbance at 554 nm as a function of irradiation time using a 756 CRT UV–vis spectrophotometer. Then UV spectra of the solutions were recorded after irradiated by two 4-W UV lamps with λmax = 365 nm (Philips, TUV 4 W/G4T5) for 2 h, which gave the corresponding RhB concentration.

    X-ray Crystallographic Study

    X-ray diffraction analysis data for compound 1 were collected on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer, with Mo–Kα monochromatic radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL package.(13) Hydrogen atoms attached to water molecules were not located but included in the structure factor calculations. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for them is provided in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles of compound 1 are listed in Tables S1 (Supporting Information). Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC number of 775926.
    Table 1. Crystal Data and Structure Refinements for Compound 1
    compound1
    formulaC50H71Ag7N20O63P2W18
    fw6086.34

    c (Å)19.9620(15)

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Photocatalytic Activity
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References

    Crystal Structure of Compound 1

    Single crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that compound 1 consists of α-[P2W18O62]6– (abbreviated as P2W18) polyanions, Ag+ monomers, {Ag2}2+ dimers, bbi ligands, and hydroxyl(14) (Figure 1). P2W18 polyanion contains two [α-A-PW9O34]9– units derived from the α-Keggin polyanion by removal of a set of three corner-shared WO6 octahedra.(15) The P–O and W–O lengths are in the normal ranges. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1, Supporting Information.
    In compound 1, each P2W18 polyanion acts as a penta-dentate ligand coordinating with five Ag+ ions. There are nine crystallographically unique Ag+ ions, Ag1 to Ag9. In the structure, the distances between Ag1 and Ag9, Ag2 and Ag2, Ag7 and Ag7 are 3.163, 3.152, and 3.312 Å, respectively, which are shorter than the van der Waals radii of two silver atoms (3.44 Å).(16) Therefore, the Ag+ ions could be classified into two kinds: the Ag+ monomer (Ag3, Ag4, Ag5, Ag6, and Ag8) and the {Ag2}2+ dimer (Ag1···Ag9, Ag2···Ag2, and Ag7···Ag7). The Ag+ monomers all adopt a linear coordination mode by coordinating with two nitrogen atoms from two bbi ligands. In the {Ag2}2+ dimers, Ag2 coordinates with two oxygen atoms from two P2W18 polyanions and one nitrogen atom from a bbi ligand; Ag7 coordinates with two nitrogen atoms from two bbi ligands; Ag9 coordinates with three oxygen atoms from two P2W18 polyanions and one nitrogen atom from a bbi ligand. The coordination mode of Ag1 is unique in that it further coordinates with two carbon atoms through weak Ag+–π interactions (Ag1···C10 = 2.374(19) Å and Ag1···C50 = 2.437(18) Å), besides one oxygen atom from the P2W18 polyanion and one nitrogen atom from the bbi ligand.(17) As a result, the Ag1···Ag9 dimer is supported by a bbi ligand and a P2W18 polyanion, and the Ag2···Ag2 dimer is supported by two P2W18 polyanions. The Ag7···Ag7 dimer is unsupported (Figure 2). The bbi ligands can be divided into three kinds according to their coordination fashions and the number of Ag+ ions attached: Type a, two terminal nitrogen atoms coordinate to two Ag+ ions; Type b, like Type a, but an imidazole group additionally coordinates with a third Ag+ ion through Ag+–π interaction; Type c, one terminal nitrogen atom coordinates to a Ag+ ion, and the other one to a {Ag2}2+ dimer(18) (Figure 3).
    The whole structure of compound 1 shows an interpenetrating architecture composed of two independent motifs, a 3D framework, and a 2D layer. In the 3D framework motif, the P2W18 polyanions are linked by the supported {Ag2}2+ dimers (Ag1···Ag9 and Ag2···Ag2) through W–O–Ag bonds, to form a one-dimensional (1D) {Ag2}2+–P2W18 chain (Figure 4b). The 1D chains are further extended to a 2D layer (layer {Ag2}2+–P2W18–Ag4) via horizontal connections of Ag4–bbi segments, and then the 2D layers are connected to a 3D framework by the longitudinal extension of Ag5–bbi segments (Figure 4a). In the 2D layer motif, first, bbi and Ag+ bond together in the order of ···Ag3–bbi–Ag8–bbi–Ag3–bbi–Ag7–bbi–Ag6–bbi–Ag7···, to form a meso-helix chain (Figure 5).(19) Furthermore, these chains are stitched to a 2D layer with loops by the unsupported Ag7···Ag7 dimers. Of particular note are the loops, each of which is composed of 14 Ag+ and 12 bbi (Figure 6), and this is quite unusual in coordination polymers or in POM-based compounds.
    The huge loop is alternately threaded by the staff of {Ag2}2+–P2W18 and the staff of Ag4–bbi from three grid layers of {Ag2}2+–P2W18–Ag4 (Figure 7). As a result, a 2D + 3D interpenetrating framework is formed (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

    Discussion of the Structural Features of Compound 1

    In POM chemistry, more and more examples of interpenetrating structure have been reported. They could be sorted to three types according to interpenetrating fashions: Type I, the same polymeric motifs containing POM clusters interpenetrate each other, which is a common fashion;(7a, 7b, 20) Type II, metal–organic coordination polymers construct the interpenetrating framework, while POM clusters fill in the space;(21) Type III, polymeric motifs of different dimensionality interpenetrate each other, for which only one example (2D + 3D) has been found.(22) Thus, compound 1 belongs to Type III. It is known that interpenetrating frameworks are often formed when large voids of a framework are occupied by other networks. In compound 1, there are two motifs of 2D and 3D. The 3D motif including large Wells–Dawson polyanions perhaps has not enough space to form the interpenetration framework of Type I, and the interpenetration is realized through penetration into the 2D layer motif composed of flexible Cu-bbi chains. Compound 1 is the second example of Type III and represents the first Wells–Dawson POM-based interpenetrating framework; especially, the interpenetration is formed by AgI···AgI interactions.
    In the case of compound 1, the AgI···AgI interactions play different roles: The supported {Ag2}2+ dimers (Ag1···Ag9 and Ag2···Ag2) play an assistant role in constructing the 3D motif, and the 3D structure would still be integrated without the AgI···AgI interactions, whereas the unsupported {Ag2}2+ dimers (Ag7···Ag7) play a key role in the formation of the interpenetrating framework, stitching the Ag-bbi chains to the 2D motif and further achieving the interpenetrating structure.

    XRPD, IR, UV–vis Absorption Spectra, and TG Analyses

    XRPD experiments were carried out for compound 1 before and after photocatalytic degradation of RhB under UV irradiation. The XRPD patterns are presented in Figure S2, Supporting Information. The diffraction peaks of the simulated and experimental pattern match well, indicating the phase purity of compound 1. Furthermore, the XRPD pattern of compound 1 after the photocatalytic experiment does not show observable change.
    The IR spectrum of compound 1 is shown in Figure S3, Supporting Information. In the spectrum, characteristic bands at 1087, 954, 909, and 783 cm–1 are attributed to ν(P–O), ν(W = O), and ν(W–O–W), respectively. Bands in the regions of 1708–1236 cm–1 are characteristics of bbi ligands.
    In the UV–vis absorption spectrum (Figure S4, Supporting Information), there is an absorption band at about λ=266.7 nm, which represents the characteristic of the {Ag2}2+ dimers.(23)
    The TGA measurement also supports the chemical composition (Figure S5, Supporting Information). In the main weight loss region of 250 to 550 °C, the weight loss of 16.81% (calc 16.30%) could be assigned to the decomposition of organic ligands and POMs.

    Cyclic Voltammetry

    Redox property of compound 1 was studied in 1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution. The electrochemical behavior is similar to the P2W18 polyanion based compounds in acidic solution reported in the literature, which means that the active center for electrochemical redox activity is the polyanion. The light potential shifts of them could be ascribed to the differences of the chemical environments. The cyclic voltammograms for 1–CPE at different scan rates are presented in Figure 8, in the potential range of +600 to −800 mV. It can be seen that there exist three reversible redox peaks II–II′, III–III′, and IV–IV′, which could be ascribed to the three consecutive two-electron processes of W centers.(24) The half-wave potentials E1/2 = (Epa + Epc)/2 are −122.5, −360.9, and −607.9 mV, respectively. In addition, the irreversible anodic peak I at about 300 mV is assigned to the oxidation of the Ag centers.(25)
    When the scan rate is increased, the peak potentials change gradually: the cathodic peak potentials shift toward the negative direction and the corresponding anodic peak potentials to the positive direction. When the scan rates are lower than 120 mV·s–1, the peak currents are proportional to the scan rates, which indicates that the redox processes are surface-controlled, and the exchanging rate of electrons is fast; however, when the scan rates are higher than 120 mV·s–1, the peak currents are proportional to the square root of the scan rate, which indicates that the redox process of the 1–CPE is diffusion-controlled (Figure S6, Supporting Information).(26)
    POMs have been extensively used as the electrocatalysts in the electrocatalytic reductions of bromate, nitrite and hydrogen peroxide, such as reported by Dong, Keita, Toth and Anson and their co-workers.(27) Herein, 1–CPE is used to catalyze the reduction processes of bromate (Figure 9). With the addition of bromate, the two- and four-electron reduced species change unconspicuously, while the six-electron reduced species of P2W18 polyanion change sharply: the reduction peak currents gradually increase while the corresponding oxidation peak currents gradually decrease. The phenomenon suggests that the bromate is mainly reduced by the six-electron reduced species of W.

    Photocatalytic Activity

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Photocatalytic Activity
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    It is known that POMs often show photocatalytic activity in the degradation of some organic substances under UV irradiation.(28) Here the photodecomposition of RhB under UV light irradiation for different times is carried out to investigate the photocatalytic activity of compound 1. As shown in Figure 10a, the absorbance of the RhB is decreased along with the prolonging of reaction time. Twelve hours later, the absorbance of the RhB is about 67% of the original solution. However, the absorbance of RhB solution with the absence of compound 1 is almost unchanged after 12 h (Figure S7a, Supporting Information). The fact indicates that compound 1 exhibits photocatalytic activity in the degradation of RhB under UV irradiation. Figure 10b shows that with the increasing of reaction time, the C/C0 values are decreased. In addition, the insoluble AgCl and (C16H36N)6(P2W18O62)·nH2O are added in the RhB solutions instead of compound 1 for contrast (Figure S7, Supporting Information): AgCl powder did not show observable photocatalytic activity, while (C16H36N)6(P2W18O62)·nH2O powder exhibited good photocatalytic activity in the degradation of RhB under UV irradiation. The results of the control experiments indicate that the photocatalytic activity of compound 1 stems from the P2W18O626– component. An XRPD experiment was carried out again for compound 1 isolated after the photocatalytic experiment, which did not show an observable change in the XRPD patterns. This fact indicates that the framework of compound 1 is not collapsed when it suffers photocatalytic degradation of RhB under UV irradiation (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Photocatalytic Activity
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    In this paper, a new compound based on the P2W18 polyanion, Ag+ ion, and bbi has been hydrothermally synthesized. This compound provides the first Wells–Dawson POM-based interpenetrating frameworks in which the AgI···AgI interactions are crucial in the formation of the two individual motifs: the supported {Ag2}2+ dimers participate in the formation of the 3D motif and the unsupported ones stitch the Ag–bbi chains to form a 2D layer with huge loops. This work enriches the POM-based entangle frameworks and expands the role of AgI···AgI interactions in POM chemistry. Furthermore, the compound exhibits electrocatalytic properties toward the reductions of bromate and photocatalytic action for the degradation of RhB.

    This article references 28 other publications.

    1. 1
      Carlucci, L.; Ciani, G.; Proserpio, D. M. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2003, 246, 247– 289
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Polycatenation, polythreading and polyknotting in coordination network chemistry
      Carlucci, Lucia; Ciani, Gianfranco; Proserpio, Davide M.
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 246 (1-2), 247-289CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      A review is presented on polycatenation, polythreading and polyknotting in coordination network chem. The use of crystal engineering concepts produced a variety of coordination networks, many of which exhibit novel and fascinating types of entanglements of individual motifs. This review analyses the structures of a no. of entangled polymeric networks reported in these years by many groups. A topol. classification of the different interlocked and interweaved species is attempted. Wide classes of polycatenated and polythreaded species were recognized and other phenomena, as polyknotting (self-penetration) and interweaving of 1-dimensional chains, are also discussed. Unexpected topol. features and new linkages, that were previously overviewed, were discovered, including the first examples of infinite Borromean links.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpt1Gitr0%253D&md5=5727cc4be054c01d955b47f3cd366bc5
      Batten, S. R.; Robson, R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 1998, 37, 1460– 1494
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

    2. 2
      Kitaura, R.; Seki, K.; Akiyama, G.; Kitagawa, S. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2003, 42, 428– 431
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Porous coordination-polymer crystals with gated channels specific for supercritical gases
      Kitaura, Ryo; Seki, Kenji; Akiyama, George; Kitagawa, Susumu
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2003), 42 (4), 428-431CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two new types of flexible and dynamic nanoporous frameworks (type A with mutually interdigitated 2D motifs and type B with mutually interpenetrated 3D motifs) were prepd. and examd. on their gas-adsorption properties (CO2, CH4, O2, and N2) at high pressure and ambient temp. Type A coordination polymer, [Cu(dhbc)2(4,4'-bpy)] × H2O (I), was prepd. from Cu(NO3)2, 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid (Hdhbc), and 4,4'-bipyridine (monoclinic, P2/c, a = 8.167(4), b = 11.094(8), c = 15.863(2) Å, β = 99.703(4)°, Z = 2 V = 1416(1) Å3). Release of crystal water from compd. I was obsd. during thermogravimetric anal. with increasing temp. ≤120°. Type B coordination polymer (C13H8NO4Cu) [Cu(p-OOC-C6H4-COO)·1/2(4,4'-bpy)]n was obtained from CuII terephthalate and 4,4'-bpy according to a published procedure. Type A coordination polymer was characterized by x-ray powder diffraction. Adsorption and desorption isotherms were recorded for all gases at 298 K.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXhtFKgtLY%253D&md5=3f7e420f3c700d4c35702ef32b811047
      Ermer, O. Adv. Mater. 1991, 3, 608– 611
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Sevenfold diamond structure and conductivity of copper dicyanoquinonediimines Cu(DCNQI)2
      Ermer, Otto
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (1991), 3 (12), 608-11CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648.
      The present communication contributes toward a more fundamental understanding of the role of the substituents in controlling the cond. of these systems. The diamondoid crystal structure of copper dicyanoquinonediimine radical anion salts Cu(DCNQI)2 should be taken into account when discussing conductivities. The analogies with multiple hydrogen bonded super-diamond structures are pointed out. The authors' new picture of the interrelation between structure and cond. is purely qual.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xhs1egsLY%253D&md5=1e04d89b99ff2732d9eb16b29ab48784
      Li, F.; Ketelaar, T.; Marcelis, A. T. M.; Leermakers, F. A. M.; Stuart, M. A. C.; Sudhö1lter, E. J. R. Macromolecules 2007, 40, 329– 333
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Stabilization of Polymersome Vesicles by an Interpenetrating Polymer Network
      Li, Feng; Ketelaar, Tijs; Marcelis, Antonius T. M.; Leermakers, Frans A. M.; Cohen Stuart, Martien A.; Sudhoelter, Ernst J. R.
      Macromolecules (2007), 40 (2), 329-333CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
      Vesicles from Pluronic L121 (PEO5-PPO68-PEO5) triblock copolymers were stabilized by an interpenetrating polymer network from pentaerythritol tetraacrylate by UV or thermal initiator induced radical polymn. Fluorescence labeling, at. force microscopy, and electron microscopy studies were used to study the morphol. of the particles and showed that stable vesicles are formed. The block copolymers are noncovalently trapped in the interpenetrating polyacrylate network. The stabilized vesicles retain their size for more than 1 mo at room temp. Upon cooling, the vesicles reversibly lose block copolymer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xhtlekt7nL&md5=8e81963b89a8297942ef131d40f38671
    3. 3
      Carlucci, L.; Ciani, G.; Proserpiob, D. M.; Rizzatob, S. CrystEngComm 2002, 4, 121– 129
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      New polymeric networks from the self-assembly of silver(I) salts and the flexible ligand 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp). A systematic investigation of the effects of the counterions and a survey of the coordination polymers based on bpp
      Carlucci, Lucia; Ciani, Gianfranco; Proserpio, Davide M.; Rizzato, Silvia
      CrystEngComm (2002), 4 (), 121-129CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The self-assembly of polymeric networks from different Ag(I) salts and the flexible ligand 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) was systematically studied to obtain some basic information useful for the crystal engineering of coordination frames upon variation of the counterions. The salts AgNO3, AgBF4, AgClO4, AgPF6, AgAsF6 and AgSbF6 were reacted in the molar ratio Ag bpp of 1:2. Though in some cases the authors obsd. the formation of mixts., contg. also minor amts. of the 1:1 [Ag(bpp)]X, the [Ag(bpp)2]X derivs. were obtained for all the salts, and all of the isolated cryst. products were characterized by single-crystal x-ray anal. Polymeric 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional networks were obsd., exhibiting four different structural motifs: [Ag(bpp)2](NO3) (1) contains 2-dimensional layers of square meshes that show 2-fold parallel interpenetration; compds. [Ag(bpp)2](BF4) (2) and [Ag(bpp)2](ClO4) (3) are isomorphous and contain 2-fold interpenetrated diamondoid networks; more surprisingly, compds. [Ag(bpp)2](PF6) (4) and [Ag(bpp)2](AsF6) (5) show a wafer-like structure contg., for the 1st time, 2-fold entangled (4,4) layers alternated to simple (4,4) layers; and finally [Ag(bpp)2](SbF6) (6) contains single 2-dimensional layers of tessellated 4-membered rings. A brief anal. of the know coordination polymers based on the bpp ligand is also reported, including the structure of [Cu(NO3)2(bpp)]2·2CH2Cl2, a mol. ring that represents the unique example showing the GG conformation for the bpp ligands.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XjsVKjtbg%253D&md5=60229c11f9dcd0d003f0a02f2226a94f

      Enantiomerically pure chiral {Fe28} wheels
      Zhang, Zhi-Ming; Li, Yang-Guang; Yao, Shuang; Wang, En-Bo; Wang, Yong-Hui; Clerac, Rodolphe
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (9), 1581-1584CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two enantiomerically pure chiral [Fe28(μ3-O)8(tart)16(CH3COO)24]20- aggregregates were synthesized from the acetate buffer soln. contg. ferric ions and chiral tartrate ligands. These compds. are the largest chiral ferric aggregates isolated to date.

      Protein-Sized Chiral Fe168 Cages with NbO-Type Topology
      Zhang, Zhi-Ming; Yao, Shuang; Li, Yang-Guang; Clerac, Rodolphe; Lu, Ying; Su, Zhong-Min; Wang, En-Bo
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (41), 14600-14601CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Protein-sized chiral Fe168 cages with NbO-type topol. Na96[Na24Fe168(L-Tart)96(u3-O)48(HCOO)144]· 310 H2O (L-Fe168) and Na96[Na24Fe168(D-Tart)96(u3-O)48(HCOO)144]· 310 H2O (D-Fe168) were successfully prepd. by the introduction of L- and D-tartrate ligands into the Fe3+/formate/Na+ systems exhibiting alc.-guest sorption properties. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that both compds. contain a cage-like Fe168 basic unit, consisting of 6 homochiral wheel-like (Fe28) building blocks and 12 cubane-like (Na4) linking units. These protein-sized enantiomerically pure chiral Fe168 cages with a 3D NbO-type open framework each exhibit an alc.-guest sorption property.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtF2ltb7L&md5=d40027225911234873b2341625b04118
      Zheng, S.-T.; Zhang, J.; Li, X.-X.; Fang, W.-H.; Yang, G.-Y. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 15102– 15103
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Cubic Polyoxometalate-Organic Molecular Cage
      Zheng, Shou-Tian; Zhang, Jie; Li, Xin-Xiong; Fang, Wei-Hui; Yang, Guo-Yu
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (43), 15102-15103CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane (Tris) was successfully grafted onto the surface of a Ni6-substituted polyoxotungstate formed in situ to further generate a three-connected polyoxometalate building block. The cooperative assembly of Tris functionalized three-connected building blocks and rigid 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate gave rise to an unprecedented cubic polyoxometalate-org. mol. cage [Ni(en)2(H2O)2]6[Ni6(Tris)(en)3(BTC)1.5(B-PW9034)]8·12en·54H2O (1. en = ethylenediamine, BTC = 1.3.5-benzenetricarboxylate) with high thermal and hydrothermal stability. The cooperative assembly of Tris functionalized three-connected building blocks and rigid 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate gave rise to an unprecedented cubic polyoxometalate-org. mol. cage [Ni(en)2(H2O)2]6[Ni6(Tris)(en)3(BTC)1.5(B-PW9034)]8·12en·54H2O (1. en = ethylenediamine, BTC = 1.3.5-benzenetricarboxylate) with high thermal and hydrothermal stability. The structure of Ni6PW9 can be described as a well-known trilacunary Keggin B-α-[PW9034]9- unit capped by a hexanuclear nickel cluster (Ni6). X-ray analyses reveal that 1 crystallizes in the hexagonal space group R3 and exhibits a POM-org. mol. cage constructed from 8 Tris-grafted Ni6PW9 SBUs and 12 BTC linkers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXht1Cgs7nP&md5=7eb6c9dd5263f1e4c73b39011df6ca73
      Gao, G.-G.; Xu, L.; Wang, W.-J.; Qu, X.-S.; Liu, H.; Yang, Y.-Y. Inorg. Chem. 2008, 47, 2325– 2333
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Cobalt(II)/Nickel(II)-Centered Keggin-Type Heteropolymolybdates: Syntheses, Crystal Structures, Magnetic and Electrochemical Properties
      Gao, Guang-Gang; Xu, Lin; Wang, Wen-Ju; Qu, Xiao-Shu; Liu, Hong; Yang, Yan-Yan
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 47 (7), 2325-2333CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      New Keggin-type Co(II)/Ni(II)-centered heteropolymolybdates, (C3H5N2)6[CoIIMo12O40]·10H2O (1) and (NH4)3(C4H5N2O2)3[NiIIMo12O40] (2), were isolated and characterized by IR, UV-visible, single-crystal x-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric, magnetic, as well as electrochem. analyses. The polyanion in the two compds. displays the known α-Keggin structure, which is composed of four Mo3O13 units formed by edge-sharing octahedra. Four Mo3O13 units connect each other by vertexes, and the Co2+ or Ni2+ is located in the center. Magnetic measurements show that the central Co2+ and Ni2+ are in high spin states (with S = 3/2 and S = 1, resp.) exhibiting paramagnetic behaviors. Cyclic voltammetric expts. for 1 represent a quasi-reversible 1-electron redox Co3+/Co2+ couple and two four-electron reversible redox processes ascribed to Mo centers, while 2 only shows two four-electron redox processes attributed to Mo centers in pH = 0.5 H2SO4 soln.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXitlejur0%253D&md5=084a1c153526e0eeef67983781a581f0
      Zhang, C.-D.; Liu, S.-X.; Ma, F.-J.; Tan, R.-K.; Zhang, W.; Su, Z.-M. Dalton Trans. 2010, 39, 8033– 8037
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Coordination between [H2P2W12O48]12- and antimony(III): synthesis and characterization of sandwich complex derived from the new {P2W13O51} fragment
      Zhang, Chun-Dan; Liu, Shu-Xia; Ma, Feng-Ji; Tan, Rui-Kang; Zhang, Wei; Su, Zhong-Min
      Dalton Transactions (2010), 39 (34), 8033-8037CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A sandwich-type anionic cluster of a new lacunary building block [P2W13O51]14- was prepd. [H6{P2W13O51}2Sb4]10- (1) was synthesized in a 1-pot self-assembly reaction of [H2P2W12O48]12- with C4H4KO7Sb·0.5H2O and characterized by single-crystal x-ray anal., IR, TGA, elemental anal., UV, NMR and electrochem. 1 Represents the 1st dimetric, Sb-contg. polyoxoanion derived from a vacant Dawson-type tungstophosphate.

      Sun, C.-Y.; Liu, S.-X.; Liang, D.-D.; Shao, K.-Z.; Ren, Y.-H.; Su, Z.-M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 1883– 1888

      5
      Highly Stable Crystalline Catalysts Based on a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework and Polyoxometalates
      Sun, Chun-Yan; Liu, Shu-Xia; Liang, Da-Dong; Shao, Kui-Zhan; Ren, Yuan-Hang; Su, Zhong-Min
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (5), 1883-1888CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of cryst. compds. [Cu2(BTC)4/3(H2O)2]6[HnXM12O40]·(C4H12N)2 (X = Si, Ge, P, As; M = W, Mo) were obtained by simple one-step hydrothermal reaction of copper nitrate, benzene tricarboxylate (BTC), and different Keggin polyoxometalates (POMs). In these compds., the catalytically active Keggin polyanions were alternately arrayed as non-coordinating guests in the cuboctahedral cages of a Cu-BTC-based metal-org. framework (MOF) host matrix. X-ray crystallog., TG, FT-IR, UV-vis, N2 adsorption studies, and acid-base titrn. demonstrated high stability and tolerance for thermal and acid-base conditions. No POM leaching or framework decompn. was obsd. The performance as catalyst of a compd. contg. PW12 species was assessed through the hydrolysis of esters in excess water; high catalytic activity was obsd. and the catalyst can be used repeatedly without activity loss. The catalytic selectivity is dependent on mol. size of substrates and substrate accessibility to the pore surface. The well-defined, cryst., MOF-supported POM compd. is a true heterogeneous acid catalyst.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Gao, G.-G.; Cheng, P.-S.; Mak, T. C. W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 18257– 18259
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Acid-Induced Surface Functionalization of Polyoxometalate by Enclosure in a Polyhedral Silver-Alkynyl Cage
      Gao, Guang-Gang; Cheng, Ping-Shing; Mak, Thomas C.-W.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (51), 18257-18259CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Surface functionalization of polyoxometalate anions with silver(I) tert-butylethynide in an org. soln. medium has been achieved for the first time using an acid-induced facile approach. The generated neutral hybrid monomeric complexes [Ag40(C≡CtBu)22(CF3COO)12(V10O28)]·4CH3OH (1) and [Ag40(C≡CtBu)20(CF3COO)12(Mo6O22)]·2CH3OH (2) constitute members of a new silver(I)-polyoxometalate family in which the polyoxometalate anion is embedded in a polyhedral silver(I) cluster assembled by multiple argentophilic Ag···Ag interactions.

      Self-assembly of nanometer-scale [Cu24I10L12]14+ cages and ball-shaped Keggin clusters into a (4,12)-connected 3D framework with photoluminescent and electrochemical properties
      Wang, Xin-Long; Qin, Chao; Wang, En-Bo; Su, Zhong-Min; Li, Yang-Guang; Xu, Lin
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (44), 7411-7414CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Bridging two traditional but distinct research areas-polyoxometalate chem. and cuprous halide clusters - the (4,12)-connected 3-dimensional framework (NH4)[Cu24I10L12][PMoV2MoVI10O40]3 was built by covalent linkage of nanoscale Keggin anions and [Cu24I10L12]14+ clusters; it exhibits remarkable photoluminescent and electrochem. properties.

      Chiral 3D architectures with helical channels constructed from polyoxometalate clusters and copper-amino acid complexes
      An, Hai-Yan; Wang, En-Bo; Xiao, Dong-Rong; Li, Yang-Guang; Su, Zhong-Min; Xu, Lin
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (6), 904-908CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Both enantiomers of a new chiral material KH2[(D(or L)-C5H8NO2)4(H2O)Cu3][BW12O40]·5H2O were synthesized by a rational approach, using enantiopure D(or L)-proline (C5H9NO2), Cu cations, and Keggin polyoxometalate (POM) anions as building blocks. The compds. have open-framework structures contg. helical channels as detd. by x-ray crystallog. Their CD spectra in water reveal significant induced optical activity in the POM moieties.

      Wang, X.-H.; Liu, J.-F.; Pope, M. T. Dalton Trans. 2003, 957– 960

      6
      New polyoxometalate/starch nanomaterial: synthesis, characterization and antitumoral activity
      Wang, Xiaohong; Liu, Jingfu; Pope, M. T.
      Dalton Transactions (2003), (5), 957-960CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Using a reversed-phase microemulsion polymn. method, polyoxometalate (POM) CoW11TiO40 loaded starch nanoparticles have been prepd. and structurally characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, UV-vis and ESR spectroscopy. The particle size of CoW11TiO40/starch was estd. by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and the size ranges by a 1000HSA MALVIRN Zetasizer instrument. The results show that the POMs retained the parent structure after encapsulated by starch microspheres, which are able to enhance the stability and antitumoral activity of POMs and also decrease the toxicity of the POM.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXhsVaksLo%253D&md5=00e712f869d9703d077f05ae7c2564c4
      Coronado, E.; Galán-Mascarós, J. R.; Giménez-Saiz, C.; Gómez-García, C. J.; Martínez-Ferrero, E.; Almeida, M.; Lopes, E. B. Adv. Mater. 2004, 16, 324– 327
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Metallic conductivity in a polyoxovanadate radical salt of bis(ethylenedithio)tetrathiafulvalene (BEDT-TTF): synthesis, structure, and physical characterization of β"-(BEDT-TTF)5[H3V10O28]·4H2O
      Coronado, Eugenio; Galan-Mascaros, Jose R.; Gimenez-Saiz, Carlos; Gomez-Garcia, Carlos J.; Martinez-Ferrero, Eugenia; Almeida, Manuel; Lopes, Elsa B.
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2004), 16 (4), 324-327CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The first radical salt of BEDT-TTF with a polyoxovanadate has been prepd. and characterized as a metal. This is also the first example of a radical salt formed by the BEDT-TTF org. donor and a polyoxometalate with a wide range of metallic cond.; the high cond. obsd. at room temp. is also noteworthy. This work opens the way for new radical salts based on polyoxovanadates, with special interest in salts analogous to the title compd. obtained by varying the oxidn. state of the polyoxovanadate, which can be reduced by several electrons. If the structural features can be maintained, this would allow us to vary the population of the conduction band of the org. layer and therefore to tune the conduction properties.

      Recent advances in polyoxometalate-containing molecular conductors
      Coronado, Eugenio; Gimenez-Saiz, Carlos; Gomez-Garcia, Carlos J.
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2005), 249 (17-18), 1776-1796CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. The recent advances in cryst. conducting mol. materials based on polyoxometalates (POMs) and org. donors of the tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) family or perylene are discussed. We emphasize the wide diversity of POM structural types and the variety of packing architectures for the org. mols. that can be induced by these inorg. anions. Besides structural effects, we show that these hybrids can have interesting elec. and/or magnetic properties. Thus, in the last years the common belief that this type of radical salts contg. such big and highly charged anions could only exhibit poor conducting properties was refuted by the prodn. of new materials exhibiting higher and higher conductivities and even metallic behavior down to very low temps.

      Highly Selective Sorption of Small Unsaturated Hydrocarbons by Nonporous Flexible Framework with Silver Ion
      Uchida, Sayaka; Kawamoto, Ryosuke; Tagami, Hanae; Nakagawa, Yoshinao; Mizuno, Noritaka
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (37), 12370-12376CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Ag2[Cr3O(OOCC2H5)6(H2O)3]2[α-SiW12O40] [1] is a nonporous flexible ionic crystal composed of 2D-layers of polyoxometalates ([α-SiW12O40]4-) and macrocations ([Cr3O(OOCC2H5)6(H2O)3]+) stacking along the b-axis. The silver ions are located in the vicinity of the oxygen atoms of the polyoxometalates. The sorption amts. of small unsatd. hydrocarbons such as ethylene, propylene, n-butene, acetylene, and Me acetylene into 1 are comparable to or larger than 1.0 mol mol-1 and large hystereses are obsd., while those of paraffins and larger unsatd. hydrocarbons are smaller than the adsorption on the external surface (<0.2 mol mol-1). Fine crystals of 1 exhibit ethylene/ethane and propylene/propane sorption ratios over 100 at 298 K and 100 kPa, and the values are larger by 1 order of magnitude among those reported. The results of sorption kinetics, in situ IR spectroscopy, single crystal X-ray crystallog., and in situ powder XRD studies show that small unsatd. hydrocarbons penetrate into the solid bulk of 1 through the π-complexation with Ag+. The sorption property of 1 is successfully applied to the collection of ethylene from the gas mixt. of ethane and ethylene.

      Photochemical studies of the alkylammonium molybdates. Part 7. Octahedral sites for multielectron reduction of [Mo8O26(MoO4)2]8-
      Yamase, Toshihiro
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions: Inorganic Chemistry (1972-1999) (1985), (12), 2585-90CODEN: JCDTBI; ISSN:0300-9246.
      Single-crystal ESR spectra of UV-irradiated (MeNH3)8[Mo8O26(MoO4)2].2H2O showed the formation of 2 distinct localized Mo(V)O5(OH) sites, resulting from H-bonding proton transfer from [MeNH3]+ to a bridging O in the anion. The H 1s orbital participates directly in the semioccupied MO with a spin population of 0.96-0.97 in Mo 4d orbitals. From the direction of the max. principal value of the 1H superfine tensor, which lies close to the Mo(V)...H+(O) direction, 2 paramagnetic sites on the anion were identified. One site has an arrangement of a MoO4 group and 2 terminal O atoms about the central Mo whereas the other site comprises one terminal and 5 bridging O atoms. The [Mo8O26(MoO4)2]8- anion undergoes a simultaneous multielectron (≤4) photochem. redn.

      An interesting fourfold interpenetrating network constructed by polyoxometalates and metal-organic coordination complexes: [CuI5(bpy)5(H2O)2][[CuII(H2O)3]2CuII[P4MoV6O25(OH)6]2]·H3O+·2H2O

      Silver-Catalyzed Late-Stage Fluorination
      Tang, Pingping; Furuya, Takeru; Ritter, Tobias
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (34), 12150-12154CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Carbon-fluorine bond formation by transition metal catalysis is difficult, and only a few methods for the synthesis of aryl fluorides have been developed. All reported transition-metal-catalyzed fluorination reactions for the synthesis of functionalized arenes are based on palladium. Here, we present silver catalysis for carbon-fluorine bond formation. For example, reacting 4-EtO2CC6H4SnBu3 with Ag2O/NaOTf/NaHCO3/MeOH gave 92% of 4-FC6H4CO2Et. Our report is the first example of the use of the transition metal silver to form carbon-heteroatom bonds by cross-coupling catalysis. The functional group tolerance and substrate scope presented here have not been demonstrated for any other fluorination reaction to date.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpvFKit7k%253D&md5=1ceb5ec71433892f9f24887d420dd057
      Selva, J.; Martínez, S. E.; Buceta, D.; Rodríguez-Vázquez, M. J.; Blanco, M. C.; López-Quintela, M. A.; Egea, G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 6947– 6954
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Silver Sub-nanoclusters Electrocatalyze Ethanol Oxidation and Provide Protection against Ethanol Toxicity in Cultured Mammalian Cells
      Selva, Javier; Martinez, Susana E.; Buceta, David; Rodriguez-Vazquez, Maria J.; Blanco, M. Carmen; Lopez-Quintela, M. Arturo; Egea, Gustavo
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (20), 6947-6954CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Silver at. quantum clusters (AgAQCs), with two or three silver atoms, show electrocatalytic activities that are not found in nanoparticles or in bulk silver. AgAQCs supported on glassy carbon electrodes oxidize ethanol and other alcs. in macroscopic electrochem. cells in acidic and basic media. This electrocatalysis occurs at very low potentials (from ∼ +200 mV vs. RHE), at physiol. pH, and at ethanol concns. that are found in alc. patients. When mammalian cells are coexposed to ethanol and AgAQCs, alc.-induced alterations such as rounded cell morphol., disorganization of the actin cytoskeleton, and activation of caspase-3 are all prevented. This cytoprotective effect of AgAQCs is also obsd. in primary cultures of newborn rat astrocytes exposed to ethanol, which is a cellular model of fetal alc. syndrome. AgAQCs oxidize ethanol from the culture medium only when ethanol and AgAQCs are added to cells simultaneously, which suggests that cytoprotection by AgAQCs is provided by the ethanol electro-oxidn. meditated by the combined action of AgAQCs and cells. Overall, these findings not only show that AgAQCs are efficient electrocatalysts at physiol. pH and prevent ethanol toxicity in cultured mammalian cells, but also suggest that AgAQCs could be used to modify redox reactions and in this way promote or inhibit biol. reactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjtVOqsLw%253D&md5=8371cad05ae8ac068fc01953d4b5c858
      Yanagisawa, A.; Nakashima, H.; Ishiba, A.; Yamamoto, H. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1996, 118, 4723– 4724
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Catalytic Asymmetric Allylation of Aldehydes Using a Chiral Silver(I) Complex
      Yanagisawa, Akira; Nakashima, Hiroshi; Ishiba, Atsushi; Yamamoto, Hisashi
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1996), 118 (19), 4723-4CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A new catalytic enantioselective allylation reaction of aldehydes with allyltributyltin was achieved using BINAP-silver(I) complex as a catalyst. The BINAP-silver(I) catalyst was prepd. by stirring an equimolar mixt. of (S)-BINAP and silver(I) triflate in THF at room temp. for 10 min. Treatment of benzaldehyde with allyltributyltin (1 equiv) in THF under influence of this catalyst (5 mol%) at -20° for 8 h gave the (S)-enriched homoallylic alc. in 88% yield with 96% ee. The reaction of a variety of arom. aldehydes and α,β-unsatd. aldehydes resulted in high yields and remarkable enantioselectivities. Addns. of methylallylstannanes to aldehydes were also achieved highly enantioselectively using this method. The BINAP·Ag(I) complex is suggested to act as a chiral Lewis acid catalyst rather than an allylsilver reagent.

      Mononuclear, dinuclear, hexanuclear, and one-dimensional polymeric silver complexes having ligand-supported and unsupported argentophilic interactions stabilized by pincer-like 2,6-bis(5-pyrazolyl)pyridine ligands
      Zhou, Yongbo; Chen, Wanzhi; Wang, Daqi
      Dalton Transactions (2008), (11), 1444-1453CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Mononuclear [Ag(H2L1)(Py)2](NO3)·H2O (1, H2L1 = 2,6-bis(5-methyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)pyridine) and [Ag(NO3)(L2)] (2, L2 = 2,6-bis(5-methyl-1-isopropyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)pyridine), dinuclear complex [Ag2(H2L3)2(HL4)2] (3, H2L3 = 2,6-bis(5-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)pyridine, HL4 = 6-(5-phenyl-1H-pyrazolyl-3-yl)picolinate), 1-dimensional polymer {[Ag2(H2L1)2](NO3)2·H2O}n (4), and hexanuclear clusters [Ag6(HL1)4](X)2 (X = NO3-, 5; BF4-, 6; ClO4-, 7) stabilized by pincer-like bispyrazolyl ligands were prepd. and characterized using 1H NMR spectroscopy, elemental anal., IR spectroscopy, luminescence spectroscopy and x-ray diffraction. In complex 3, there is a ligand unsupported Ag-Ag bond between the two Ag atoms. Complex 4 displays a 1-dimensional polymer consisting of an infinite Ag-Ag chain and every two adjacent Ag ions are bridged by an H2L1 ligand. Complexes 5 and 7 have the same Ag6 cores in which six Ag atoms are held together by four HL1 and five Ag-Ag bonds, while complex 6 was held together by six Ag-Ag bonds. The Ag-Ag distances in these complexes are found at 2.874(1)-3.333(2) Å for ligand supported, and 3.040(1) Å for ligand unsupported Ag-Ag bonds, resp. Complexes 3-7 are strongly luminescent due to either intraligand or metal-ligand charge transfer processes.

      Structural diversity of N-heterocyclic carbene complexes of silver(I)
      Lee, Kwang Ming; Wang, Harrison M. J.; Lin, Ivan J. B.
      Journal of the Chemical Society, Dalton Transactions (2002), (14), 2852-2856CODEN: JCSDAA; ISSN:1472-7773. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Seven N-heterocyclic carbene complexes of silver(I) have been synthesized, five of which were structurally characterized. Polymeric AgI-carbene complexes with a diverse range of structures are formed through extended AgI-AgI interactions, AgI-bridging halides, AgI-bridging dicarbenes, and ring π-π interactions. Compds. having extended AgI-AgI-centered interactions exhibit low energy emission bands at λmax ≈ 540 nm. These bands are assigned to metal-centered transitions involving extended AgI-AgI interactions.

      10
      Ligand and Counterion Control of Ag(I) Architectures: Assembly of a {Ag8} Ring Cluster Mediated by Hydrophobic and Ag···Ag Interactions
      Fielden, John; Long, De-liang; Slawin, Alexandra M. Z.; Koegerler, Paul; Cronin, Leroy
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 46 (22), 9090-9097CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A strategy combining ligand design and counterion variation was used to study the assembly of silver(I) complexes. As a result, dinuclear, octanuclear, and polymeric silver(I) species were synthesized by complexation of the rigid aliph. amino ligands cis-3,5-diamino-trans-hydroxycyclohexane (DAHC), cis-3,5-diamino-trans-methoxycyclohexane (DAMC), and cis-3,5-diamino-trans-tert-butyldimethylsilyloxycyclohexane (DATC) with silver(I) triflate, nitrate, and perchlorate. The compns. of these aggregates, established by x-ray crystallog. and elemental anal., are [{Ag(DAHC)}2](CF3SO3)2 (1), [{Ag(DAMC)}2](CF3SO3)2 (2), [{Ag(DAMC)}2](NO3)2 (3), [{Ag(DATC)}6{Ag(DAHC)}2](NO3)8 (4), and [{Ag(DATC)}n](NO3)n (5), where the DAHC present in 4 is formed by in situ hydrolysis of the acid labile silyl ether group. The type of aggregate formed depends both upon the noncoordinating O-substituent of the ligand and the (also noncoordinating) counterion, with the normal preference of the ligand topol. for forming Ag2L2 structures being broken by introduction of the bulky, lipophilic O-tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBDMS) group. Of particular note is the octanuclear silver ring structure 4, which is isolated only when both the O-TBDMS group and the nitrate counteranion are present and is formed from four Ag2L2 dimers connected by Ag···Ag and hydrogen-bonding interactions. Diffusion rate measurement of this {Ag8} complex by 1H NMR (DOSY) indicates dissocn. in CD3OD and CD3CN, showing that this supramol. ring structure is formed upon crystn., and establishing a qual. limit to the strength of Ag···Ag interactions in soln. When solns. of the {Ag8} cluster in methanol are kept for several days though, a new UV-visible absorption is obsd. at ∼430 nm, consistent with the formation of silver nanoparticles.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVOhtrrL&md5=586284bb7ab5cff32313bc0ed020cdec
      Pickering, A. L.; Long, D.-L.; Cronin, L. Inorg. Chem. 2004, 43, 4953– 4961
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Coordination Networks through the Dimensions: From Discrete Clusters to 1D, 2D, and 3D Silver(I) Coordination Polymers with Rigid Aliphatic Amino Ligands
      Pickering, Alexandra L.; Long, De-Liang; Cronin, Leroy
      Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (16), 4953-4961CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The use of a ligand directed strategy in the assembly of discrete clusters, 1-dimensional chains, 2-dimensional layers, and 3-dimensional networks using aliph. N-donor ligands was studied. The ligands are a family of amines with rigid backbones [cis,cis-1,3,5-triaminocyclohexane (cis-tach), cis,trans-1,3,5-triaminocyclohexane (trans-tach), cis-1,3-diaminocyclohexane (cis-dach), and cis-3,5-diaminopiperidine (cis-dapi)], and their complexation with Ag(I) salts results in a diverse set of architectures with the following compns.:[Ag3(cis-tach)2]F3·4MeOH·0.5H2O (1), [Ag3(cis-tach)2]F3·6H2O (2), {[Ag(cis-dach)]ClO4}n (3), {[Ag(cis-tach)]NO3}n (4), {[Ag(trans-tach)]PF6}n (5), and {[Ag(cis-dapi)]CF3SO3}n (6). Structural anal. shows that compds. 1 and 2 are discrete M3L2 cage-type clusters with varying solvent mol. content. Short Ag···Ag contacts (3.021(8) Å) dimerize discrete units in compd. 2. Compd. 3 is a 1-dimensional zigzag chain formed by coordination to the two primary amines of cis-dach, whereas the tridentate ligands in compds. 4 and 5 (cis-tach and trans-tach, resp.) are able to form tubular architectures by virtue of their ability to wrap round the channel walls. An infinite 2-dimensional coordination network is demonstrated by compd. 6, in which the three coplanar amino donors of cis-dapi coordinate to the trigonal planar Ag(I) ions to form a layered structure of 63 topol. These are compared with a previously reported 3-dimensional structure, {[Ag(trans-tach)]NO3}n (7), that belongs to this family of architectures.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXlsVeltrY%253D&md5=f98a0204f354d4c3be78d5b95c1b7495
      Kristiansson, O. Inorg. Chem. 2001, 40, 5058– 5059
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Unusual Manifestation of Closed-Shell Interactions in Silver(I) Complexes: Crystal Structure of Catena-bis(4-aminobenzoato)disilver(I) Acetone Solvate with Ligand Unsupported Chains of Repeated Rhombohedral Ag4 Units
      Kristiansson, Olof
      Inorganic Chemistry (2001), 40 (20), 5058-5059CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A ligand unsupported Ag(I) aggregate with a higher complexity and shorter Ag-Ag distances than hitherto reported, catena(μ3-O,O',N-4-aminobenzoato)(μ2-O,N-4-aminobenzoato)disilver(I) acetone solvate, was obtained by heating 1:1 stoichiometric quantities of Ag(I) nitrate and K p-aminobenzoate in H2O/acetone. The rhombohedral units are not stabilized by bridging or capping ligands but solely linked by Ag-Ag interactions, and the Ag4 units are further linked to form infinite chains by Ag-Ag interactions supported by bis carboxylato-O,O' bridges [d(Ag-Ag) = 2.9460(6) Å].
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXmtFCmtLw%253D&md5=999a5adc81f6e1848a29a1e01b477055
    11. 11
      Streb, C.; Ritchie, C.; Long, D.-L.; Kögerler, P.; Cronin, L. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2007, 46, 7579– 7582
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Modular assembly of a functional polyoxometalate-based open framework constructed from unsupported AgI···AgI interactions
      Streb, Carsten; Ritchie, Chris; Long, De-Liang; Koegerler, Paul; Cronin, Leroy
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (40), 7579-7582CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Modular assembly of the title system, Ag(MeCN)4⊂{[Ag(MeCN)2]4[H3W12O40]}, was achieved using {H3W12O40}5- and {Ag2}2+ building blocks to give a material with [Ag(MeCN)4]+ ions in its microporous channels. This framework is constructed by unsupported AgI···AgI interactions, and sorption studies show that the framework can reversibly adsorb up to 10% MeCN.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtF2rsr7E&md5=a9301d40167dc659cf6672037e581d3b
      Abbas, H.; Streb, C.; Pickering, A. L.; Neil, A. R.; Long, D.-L.; Cronin, L. Cryst. Growth Des. 2008, 8, 635– 642

      11
      Molecular Growth of Polyoxometalate Architectures Based on [-Ag{Mo8}Ag-] Synthons: Toward Designed Cluster Assemblies
      Abbas, Hamera; Streb, Carsten; Pickering, Alexandra L.; Neil, Andrew R.; Long, De-Liang; Cronin, Leroy
      Crystal Growth & Design (2008), 8 (2), 635-642CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      The interaction of Ag(I) cations with octamolybdate [Mo8O26]4- was studied by applying the principles of the building-block concept to the well established Ag-octamolybdate reaction system. The self-assembly of dimeric {Ag2} linkers gave chains and networks where [Mo8O26]4- clusters are cross-linked by Ag(I) cations. The influence of the solvent on the overall topol. was studied, and the role of the counterion on the resulting structure was highlighted in each assembly. Fine-tuning of the metal-metal distances of the dimeric {Ag2} linking units was achieved by using different coordinating solvents which act as bridges. Five compds. based on Ag octamolybdate building blocks were isolated, including an uncommon intermediate chain like assembly ((Ph4P)2[Ag2(MeCN)2(Mo8O26)]), three 1-dimensional polymeric chains ([Ag(C7H12O2N)(MeCN)]2n[Ag2(MeCN)2(Mo8O26)]n·2MeCN, (Ph4P)2n[Ag2(DMF)2(Mo8O26)]n·2DMF, and (H2NMe2)2n[Ag2(DMF)2(Mo8O26)]n·2DMF), and a two-dimensional cross-linked network ([(Ag(DMF))2(Ag(DMF)2)2Mo8O26]n). Each compd. was characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, elemental anal., and FTIR.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsVKmt7w%253D&md5=b5e8b41052db7a43f666c603d9724a11
      Abbas, H.; Pickering, A. L.; Long, D.-L.; Kögerler, P.; Cronin, L. Chem.—Eur. J. 2005, 11, 1071– 1078
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Controllable growth of chains and grids from polyoxomolybdate building blocks linked by silver(I) dimers
      Abbas, Hamera; Pickering, Alexandra L.; Long, De-Liang; Koegerler, Paul; Cronin, Leroy
      Chemistry--A European Journal (2005), 11 (4), 1071-1078CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Mol. growth processes using a β-octamolybdate synthon and {Ag2} dimers are described and the directing influence of encapsulating cations and coordinating solvent is also demonstrated. The growth of two 1-dimensional chains, (Bu4N)2n[Ag2Mo8O26]n (1) and (Bu4N)2n[Ag2Mo8O26(MeCN)2]n (2), is achieved when Bu4N+ ions were used, and the diam. of the chains can be expanded by the coordination of MeCN solvent (2). The formation of a type of gridlike structure in which 1-dimensional chains are crossed-over each other in alternatively packed layers is achieved in DMSO as the solvent. DMSO acts as a linking group to give (Bu4N)2n[Ag2Mo8O26(DMSO)2]n (3), which, similar to 1 and 2, still incorporates the Bu4N+ ions that exert an encapsulating influence. However, in (HDMF)n[Ag3(Mo8O26)(DMF)4]n (4) the relatively bulky Bu4N+ ions are exchanged for protonated DMF cations, thereby allowing the chains to condense to a 2-dimensional array. The building block concept is further enforced by the isolation of a monomeric unit (Ph4P)2[Ag2Mo8O26(DMSO)4] (5), which is isolated when the Ph4P+ ions are so encapsulating as to prevent aggregation of the {Ag-Mo8-Ag} building blocks. The nature of the Ag···Ag dimers in each of the compds. 1-4 was examd. by DFT calcns. and the interplay between these Ag-Ag interactions and the structure types is described.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhsVahtbk%253D&md5=54baa991e9be4afa9a8483d3958ceb5e
      Pang, H.-J.; Zhang, C.-J.; Shi, D.-M.; Chen, Y.-G. Cryst. Growth Des. 2008, 8, 4476– 4480
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Synthesis of a Purely Inorganic Three-Dimensional Porous Framework Based on Polyoxometalates and 4d-4f Heterometals
      Pang, Haijun; Zhang, Chunjing; Shi, Dongmei; Chen, Yaguang
      Crystal Growth & Design (2008), 8 (12), 4476-4480CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      A new polyoxometalate-based 4d-4f heterometallic compd., [{Ag3(H2O)2}{Ce2(H2O)12}H5⊂{H2W11Ce(H2O)4O39}2]·8H2O (1), was synthesized and characterized by routine methods. In 1, the dimers constructed by two monosubstituted α-metatungstate [H2W11{Ce(H2O)4}O39]7- (simplified as {W11Ce}7-) units are linked by CeIII and AgI to form two-dimensional (2D) networks, and these networks are further connected by AgI-AgI ({Ag2}2+) bonds to obtain a purely inorg. three-dimensional (3D) framework with two kinds of channels along the [1 0 0] and [0 1 0] directions. Also, 1 exhibits reversible H2O sorption capability.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Synthesis and characterization of the highest connected 3D α-metatungstate POM/TMC hybrid with AgI···AgI interactions
      Zhang, Chun-Jing; Chen, Ya-Guang; Pang, Hai-Jun; Shi, Dong-Mei; Hu, Mi-Xia; Li, Jia
      Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2008), 11 (7), 765-768CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A novel 3D hybrid based on α-metatungstate polyoxometalate (POMs) modified with transition metal complex (TMC), Na4[Ag6L4][H2W12O40]·12H2O (1) (L = nicotinate), was prepd. and characterized by elemental anal., IR, UV, TG and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Each of the W12 clusters is surrounded by 10 Ag centers, which represents the highest connected no. of the α-metatungstate POMs to date. Addnl., compd. 1 is stable in air and shows photoluminescence at room temp.

      11
      Self-Assembly of a Series of Extended Architectures Based on Polyoxometalate Clusters and Silver Coordination Complexes
      An, Haiyan; Li, Yangguang; Wang, Enbo; Xiao, Dongrong; Sun, Chunyan; Xu, Lin
      Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (17), 6062-6070CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Three unusual compds. based on polyoxometalate building blocks, [(H2O)5Na2(C6NO2H4)(C6NO2H5)3Ag2][Ag2IMo6O24(H2O)4]·6.25H2O (1), [(H2O)4Na2(C6NO2H5)6Ag3][IMo6O24]·6H2O (2), and (C6NO2H6)2[(C6NO2H5)2Ag][Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]·4H2O (3), were synthesized and characterized by elemental anal.; IR, XPS, and ESR spectroscopy; TGA; and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Compd. 1 is constructed from the cationic two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer sheets which are constituted of [(H2O)5Na2(C6NO2H4)(C6NO2H5)3Ag2]3+ and anionic [Ag2IMo6O24(H2O)4]3- chains as pillars, forming a three-dimensional (3D) supramol. framework via weak Ag-O interactions. Compd. 2 is composed of the well-defined [IMo6O24]5- building blocks, which are linked through trinuclear Ag-pyridine-3-carboxylic acid, [(C6NO2H5)6Ag3]3+, fragments into a 1-dimensional (1D) hybrid chain; adjacent chains are further connected by Na cations to yield a novel 2-dimensional network. Compd. 3 has a 1-dimensional chainlike structure constructed from [Cr(OH)6Mo6O18]3- building blocks and Ag-pyridine-4-carboxylic acid coordination units. The crystal data for these compds. are the following: 1, triclinic, space group P‾1, a 13.280(3), b 13.641(3), c 16.356(3) Å, α 89.68(3), β 88.31(3), γ 75.87(3)°, Z = 2; 2, triclinic, P‾1, a 11.978(2), b 12.008(2), c 13.607(3) Å, α 116.14(3), β 108.85(3), γ 93.86(3)°, Z = 1; 3, triclinic, P‾1, a 10.458(2), b 10.644(2), c 12.295(3) Å, α 97.40(3), β 112.38(3), γ 113.59(3)°, Z = 1.

      A Porous Supramolecular Architecture from a Copper(II) Coordination Polymer with a 3D Four-Connected 86 Net
      Ma, Jian-Fang; Yang, Jin; Zheng, Guo-Li; Li, Li; Liu, Jing-Fu
      Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (23), 7531-7534CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A novel coordination polymer {[Cu(L1)(L2)(H2O)]·5H2O}n (1), where L1 = 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole) and L2 = m-phthalate anion, was obtained by using an unusual crystn. process (through evapg. an ammoniacal soln. of 1). It crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pna21, which belongs to the crystal class mm2, with a 9.0521(18), b 15.401(3), and c 17.141(3) Å, α = β = γ 90°, and Z = 4. The complex 1 composing a porous supramol. architecture displays unprecedented four-connected topol. of an 86 net in coordination polymer chem. TGA and x-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns for 1 imply that the framework of the compd. cannot be recovered by hydration after thermal dehydration.

      Highly oxidation resistant inorganic-porphyrin analog polyoxometalate oxidation catalysts. 1. The synthesis and characterization of aqueous-soluble potassium salts of α2-P2W17O61(Mn+·OH2)(n-10) and organic solvent soluble tetra-n-butylammonium salts of α2-P2W17O61(Mn+·Br)(n-11) (M = Mn3+,Fe3+,Co2+,Ni2+,Cu2+)
      Lyon, David K.; Miller, Warren K.; Novet, Thomas; Domaille, Peter J.; Evitt, Eric; Johnson, David C.; Finke, Richard G.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1991), 113 (19), 7209-21CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      The synthesis and characterization of isolated, isomerically pure α2-P2W17O61(Mn+.L)y- (Mn+ = Mn3+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+) as aq.-sol. K+ salts (L = H2O) and org.-sol. Bu4N+ salts (L = Br-) are reported. These complexes were characterized by elemental anal., sedimentation equil. mol. wt., TGA, temp.-varied solid-state magnetic susceptibility, UV-visible, IR, 31P, and 183W NMR spectroscopies. These compds. constitute isolated monosubstituted Dawson α2-isomer complexes that were prepd. free of the α1-isomer. Preliminary axial-base binding studies for α2-[(Bu4N]7.3H0.7P2W17O61(MnBr) are reported, and the pocket around the transition metal is hindered, but less so than in sterically congested porphyrins. α2-[Bu4N]7.3H0.7P2W17O61(MNBr) is not oxidatively degraded by 1500 equiv of PhIO even over 48 h.

      Hydrothermal synthesis, crystal structure and properties of a 3D-framework polyoxometalate assembly: [Ag(4,4'-bipy)](OH){[Ag(4,4'-bipy)]2[PAgW12O40]}·3.5H2O
      Chen, Jian-Xin; Lan, Ting-Yan; Huang, Yuan-Biao; Wei, Chun-Xia; Li, Zhong-Shui; Zhang, Zhi-Chun
      Journal of Solid State Chemistry (2006), 179 (6), 1904-1910CODEN: JSSCBI; ISSN:0022-4596. (Elsevier)
      A 3-dimensional framework assembly based on the Keggin tungstophosphate POM with silver(I) transition metal and N-ligand org. moiety, [Ag(4,4'-bipy)](OH){[Ag(4,4'-bipy)]2[PAgW12O40]}·3.5H2O (1, bipy = bipyridine), was synthesized by a hydrothermal method and structurally characterized. The crystal of 1 belongs to triclinic, space group P‾1, Mr = 3857.27, a 10.2741(3), b 11.3723(4), c 14.0161(5) Å, α 85.7249(5), β 72.8795(5), γ 79.9543(5)°, Z = 1, dc = 4.158 Mg m-3. The final statistics based on F2 are GOF = 1.045, R1 = 0.0326 and wR2 = 0.0843 for I > 2σ(I). X-ray diffraction anal. revealed that the mol. structure of 1 consists of a neutral fragment {[AgI(4,4'-bipy)]2[PAgIWVI12O40]}, [AgI(4,4'-bipy)]+ cation, hydroxide anion and lattice water mols. The {[AgI(4,4'-bipy)]2[PAgIWVI12O40]} subunits are interconnected through Ag(I) with bipyridine ligands, both surface bridging and terminal oxygen atoms of polyoxoanions (POMs) to represent a novel three-dimensional (3D) polymer with 1-dimensional elliptic channels. Meanwhile, the [AgI(4,4'-bipy)]+ cations are also linked each other to form 1-dimensional chains, and embedded in 1-dimensional elliptic channels.

      A novel 1D zigzag chain organic-inorganic polymer with Dawson-type polyoxometalates as building blocks: synthesis and crystal structure of H1.5[Sm(H2O)8]0.5[Sm(DMF)6(H2O)(α-P2W18O62)]·DMF·3H2O
      Wang, Jingping; Zhao, Junwei; Niu, Jingyang
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2004), 697 (1-3), 191-198CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      A novel 1-dimensional chain org.-inorg. polymer H1.5[Sm(H2O)8]0.5[Sm(DMF)6(H2O)(α-P2W18O62)]·DMF·3H2O with Dawson-type polyoxometalates as building blocks was synthesized by reaction of SmCl3, DMF and α-H6P2W18O62·nH2O in the mixed soln. of MeCN and H2O in the bulk ratio of 1:1 and characterized by IR, UV spectra, TG-DTA technique, electrochem. behavior and x-ray single-crystal diffraction. X-ray single-crystal structural anal. displays that the title compd. crystallizes in an orthorhombic lattice, space group P21212, with a 23.605(5), b 30.443(6), c 14.536(3) Å, α = β =γ 90°, V = 10446(4) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0493, wR2 = 0.0783. [Sm(1)(DMF)6(H2O)]3+ coordination cation is nine-coordinate with a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic environment, which is bridged through W-O-Sm(1)-O-W linkages to build an unprecedented 1-dimensional zigzag linear chain structure by alternate polyoxometalate anions and metal coordination cations in the polymer, whereas [Sm(2)(H2O)8]3+ coordination ion is a discrete unit incorporated into the gaps of the polyoxoanions with an eight-coordinate square antiprismatic geometry. Cyclic voltammetry reveals that the pH of the supporting electrolytic soln. has a marked effect on the electrochem. behavior.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      15
      New Polyoxometalate Compounds Built up of Lacunary Wells-Dawson Anions and Trivalent Lanthanide Cations
      Lu, Ying; Xu, Yan; Li, Yangguang; Wang, Enbo; Xu, Xinxin; Ma, Ying
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (5), 2055-2060CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Five new polyoxometalate compds. built on lacunary Wells-Dawson anions and trivalent lanthanide cations, KNa3[Nd2(H2O)10(α2-P2W17O61)]·11H2O (1), (H3O)[Nd3(H2O)17(α2-P2W17O61)]·6.75H2O (2), (H2bpy)2[Nd2(H2O)9 (α2-P2W17O61)]·4.5H2O (3), (H2bpy)2[La2(H2O)9(α2-P2W17O61)]·4.5H2O (4), and (H2bpy)2[Eu2(H2O)9(α2-P2W17O61)]·5H2O (5), were synthesized and characterized by elemental anal., IR, TG, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Compd. 1 shows a bisupporting polyoxometalate cluster structure where two {Nd(H2O)7}3+ fragments are supported on the polyoxometalate dimer [{Nd(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)}2]14-. This represents the 1st bisupporting polyoxometalate compd. based on a polyoxometalate dimer. Compd. 2 displays a 1-dimensional chain structure built up of bisupporting polyoxoanions [{Nd(H2O)7}2{Nd(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)}2]8- and Nd3+ ions. Compds. 3-5 are isostructural and show a 2-dimensional structure constructed of 1-dimensional polyoxometalate chains of [Ln(H2O)2(α2-P2W17O61)]n7n- linked by Ln3+ ions. Compds. 2-5 represent the 1st extended structures formed by lacunary Wells-Dawson anions and trivalent lanthanide ions. The influence of the Ln3+/[α2-P2W17O61]10- ratio on the syntheses of these five compds. was studied. Also, the fluorescent activity of compd. 5 is reported.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Strong Closed-Shell Interactions in Inorganic Chemistry

      Solid State Calix[4]arene Tubular Assemblies Based on Cation-π Interactions
      Budka, Jan; Lhotak, Pavel; Stibor, Ivan; Sykora, Jan; Cisarova, Ivana
      Supramolecular Chemistry (2003), 15 (5), 353-357CODEN: SCHEER; ISSN:1061-0278. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
      Infinite tubular assemblies based on calix[4]arenes can be easily constructed using cation-π interactions of silver triflate with pre-organized arom. subunits (1,3-alternate or pinched cone conformations). X-ray crystallog. anal. shows that the overall self-assembly is held together by triflate anions playing the role of the bridges between the individual complexes.

      [26](1,2,4,5)Cyclophane (deltaphane) and related compounds. Simultaneous π-electron interaction among three benzene rings
      Kang, Hee Chol; Hanson, A. W.; Eaton, Bruce; Boekelheide, V.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1985), 107 (7), 1979-85CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      Pyrolysis of benzodicyclobutene I at 425° gives cyclophanes II, III and IV; the last 2 were subjected to x-ray crystallog. The phys. and chem. properties of III were examd. Variable-temp. NMR studies of the Ag triflate complex of III show Ag+ undergoing rapid exchange, and x-ray crystallog. shows Ag+ complexed sym. outside the deltaphane moiety. Similar results were obtained for the Ag triflate complex of cyclophane V.

      A meso-helical coordination polymer from achiral dinuclear [Cu2(H3CCN)2(μ-pydz)3][PF6]2 and 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphanyl)propane-synthesis and crystal structure of ∞1{[Cu(μ-pydz)2][PF6]} (pydz = pyridazine)
      Plasseraud, Laurent; Maid, Harald; Hampel, Frank; Saalfrank, Rolf W.
      Chemistry--A European Journal (2001), 7 (18), 4007-4011CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      Reaction of achiral [Cu2(MeCN)2(μ-pydz)3][PF6]2 (1; pydz = pyridazine) with bidendate 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphanyl)propane (2) in MeCN at room temp. in a 1:1 ratio yielded the mononuclear Cu(I) complex [Cu{CH2(CH2PPh2)2}2][PF6] (3) together with new 1-dimensional coordination polymer ∞1{[Cu(μ-pydz)2][PF6]} (4). Air-sensitive single crystals of 4 suitable for x-ray structure detn. were grown from a mixt. of dichloromethane/hexane [crystal system: monoclinic; space group: C2/c; a 21.910(3), b 12.130(2), c 25.704(3) Å, β 110.08(10)°, V = 6416.65(16) Å3]. The 1-dimensional coordination polymer 4 exhibits as an outstanding feature the rare structure of a meso-helix.
